There you can find news about the developement of Psycle itself, plugins, songs, and a great forum with several boards (tech board, tips board, ...) where you can easily find information, help and even find the developers. That site born with Psycle (even before being added to sourceforge). That's why it remains as the reference site.

We put here, at http://psycle.sourceforge.net/, some bleeding-edge, "unofficial" builds, which are not intended to be the mainstream distribution, and files and information interesting rather the developpers than the end-users. Also, there are documents on a wiki service, which content is inherently unofficial, due to the open nature of wiki.

part.caption: Psycle based on Microsoft's Windows®™ MFC®™

part.part:
This codebase of psycle represents years of development and is quite mature. The use of Psycle's sources and binaries are currently not restricted by any licence. If the psycledelics community ever decides to use a licence, it will surely be some Free/Libre Software License, like for example the GNU Public Licence, which would strengthen its freedom.
The builds here are distributed as raw archives (no installer) containing the "doc" dir, and directories containing the binaries themselves, of the psycle host application, and all the open source native plugins.

To checkout the head of trunk (main branch) of the subversion repository, issue the following command:
svn checkout https://svn.sourceforge.net:/svnroot/psycle/trunk
Later, to update your local copy, you can just do:
cd trunk
svn update
Tip:
You can retrieve a particular revision by checking out the url: https://svn.sourceforge.net:/svnroot/psycle/tags/psycle-x.y.z-stable
Remember that if you do so, svn update will likely not give you any more changes, apart maybe bugfixes, since stable versions are mostly frozen.

Screenshots: , .
There is a Debian archive in the directory, which lists both binary-i386 packages, and source packages.
You can choose either unstable, testing or stable for the version of psycle, Note that this is independent from the main debian distribution you use: All packages are built on debian unstable, debian testing, debian stable, ubuntu dapper, ubuntu breezy, etc ...
In the following example, etch/unstable means psycle's unstable version for the debian etch distibution.
To let APT find the archive and look into it for psycle unstable binary packages compiled for the etch debian distribution, add for example (see notes above) following lines to your /etc/apt/sources.list:
# psycle binary packages
deb http://psycle.sourceforge.net/debian etch/unstable main
Then, update you local list of packages:
apt-get update
and do a search for 'psycle' with your favorite package tool, for example:
apt-cache search psycle
or,
dpkg --list '*psycle*'
If you want to install all psycle binary packages, install the psycle package which is a pseudo package with dependencies on all psycle packages:
apt-get install psycle
Note:
Currently, the archive contains binaries only for the i386 architecture. You can easily build the source packages to produce binary packages for your architecture.
For each source package, there are three versions: unstable, testing, stable
To let APT find the source archive and look into it for unstable source packages, add for example (see notes above) following lines to your /etc/apt/sources.list:
# psycle source packages
deb-src http://psycle.sourceforge.net/debian source/unstable main
Please see the paragraph about how to build psycle below for the next steps.
Note that these are untested. Please instead debootsrap a Debian or Ubuntu system in a chroot.

This is probably the most painful operating system for software distribution, as it doesn't come with any standard system for distributing packages, automatically resolving/downloading their dependencies, and with consistent versions accross all packages installed system-wide, or at least support for multiple versions simultaneously installed. (This operating system is not a distribution, it's both proprietary and anarchic).
This means we have to track all psycle's dependencies and bundle them into a custom, giant, monolithic "package", which is self-contained and not meant to be installed system-wide, but rather, locally in each user's home dir. This makes the "package" very big (it's a mini distro itself), but works around all the defficiencies mentionned above.
Anyway, here are the available, self-contained, raw "packages":

Psycle is currently distributed as several debian binary packages, but all those binary packages are built from a single source package, called psycle.
To download this source package, do:
cd /tmp
apt-get source psycle
cd psycle-*.*.*
Building the source package requires that you have some other packages installed, like a c++ compiler, linker, make, the development files of the libraries psycle depends on, etc. You can tell APT to download and install these dependency packages by issuing the following command:
apt-get build-dep psycle

Psycle's source package uses the GNU build system (autoconf, automake, libtool, pkg-config). You don't need to have these tools installed but pkg-config. Also, you will need to have a c++ compiler, linker, make, and the development files of the libraries psycle depends on.
On debian, you can tell APT to download and install these dependency packages by issuing the following command:
apt-get build-dep psycle
On other systems, to view the dependencies, read the file for the latest unstable version of the source package, or the file psycle_*.*.*.dsc in the directory for a particular version of the source package.
The GNU build system follows the standard two-step build procedure of unices source packages:
configure: detection of system characteristics, and configuration of the build options
make: execution of the make files which describe the actual build commands as configured in the previous step (compilation, linking, moving of files to installation destination)
You can also build from within the IDE of your choice.
cd psycle-*
mkdir build && cd build
../configure --prefix=$(pwd)/../psycle-install-dir
make install-strip
cd ../psycle-install-dir
tree
./bin/psycle
You can also simply use the script named ./packageneric/generic/bin/build which comes with the source package and does the mkdir && cd, configure and make steps.

jaz has taken the FT2 sampler source that Satoshi did, put it in the mainline version of psycle (MFC), and did many improvements on it, so Satoshi's original work on the FT2 sampler isn't a lost abandonned effort.

To get the HEAD revision set of the cvs (the lastest revision of each file in the trunk (main branch)), issue the following command:
cvs -d :pserver:anonymous@cvs.sourceforge.jp:/cvsroot/sftracker -z9 checkout -R -P -r HEAD SFTracker
Later, to update your local copy, you can just do:
cd SFTracker
cvs update -R -d -P
